Using the estimator in (20), Sadinle (2017) observes that the LSAP algorithm adopts a conservative approach in declaring links, in that it requires Pâ€‹(Zj=i|Î³)â‰¥.50ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—conditionalğ‘–ğ›¾.50P(Z_{j}=i|\gamma)\geq.50.
This reduces the risk of incorrect linkages, but it can introduce bias in the estimation of overlap size under certain linkage scenarios. As an example, consider a task of linking unique individuals in a large data file ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}â€”which has near complete coverage of a populationâ€”to participants in a survey data file â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B} that overlaps with ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}. Within ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}, suppose exactly two distinct individuals ğ’œ1subscriptğ’œ1\mathcal{A}_{1} and ğ’œ2subscriptğ’œ2\mathcal{A}_{2} share identical names with individual â„¬1âˆˆâ„¬subscriptâ„¬1â„¬\mathcal{B}_{1}\in\mathcal{B}. As a result, the posterior probabilities that Z1=1subscriptğ‘11Z_{1}=1 or Zj=2subscriptğ‘ğ‘—2Z_{j}=2 are both near (but necessarily below) 0.50.50.5, as exemplified in Table 1.
In this case, it is reasonable to conclude that one of ğ’œ1subscriptğ’œ1\mathcal{A}_{1} or ğ’œ2subscriptğ’œ2\mathcal{A}_{2} is the true link to â„¬1subscriptâ„¬1\mathcal{B}_{1}, and therefore to count â„¬1subscriptâ„¬1\mathcal{B}_{1} as part of the overlap population. However, if we use (20), the BRL estimate fails to declare any links for â„¬1subscriptâ„¬1\mathcal{B}_{1} in ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}, even though the chance that
â„¬1subscriptâ„¬1\mathcal{B}_{1} is not linked to any elements in ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} is only 2%. Similar issues can arise when more than two records in ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} are highly plausible links for some â„¬jsubscriptâ„¬ğ‘—\mathcal{B}_{j}.

The sufficient condition in (25) assigns a non-link to â„¬jsubscriptâ„¬ğ‘—\mathcal{B}_{j} when its posterior probability of having no links is largest.
This particular decision rule is reasonable when the posterior distribution for Zjsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—Z_{j} is characterized by large probability mass either at Zj=nğ’œ+jsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ‘›ğ’œğ‘—Z_{j}=n_{\mathcal{A}}+j or Zj=isubscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘–Z_{j}=i for some iğ‘–i. However, if the posterior distribution is multi-modal across a variety of potential links in ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}, the sufficient condition may be undesirable. To illustrate, consider the example in Table 2.
According to (25), the LSAP will result in a non-link decision. This results mainly because of significant uncertainty in the match status, as reflected through a posterior distribution with moderate probability masses placed on the decisions Zj=1subscriptğ‘ğ‘—1Z_{j}=1, Zj=2subscriptğ‘ğ‘—2Z_{j}=2, and Zj=nğ’œ+jsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ‘›ğ’œğ‘—Z_{j}=n_{\mathcal{A}}+j. In a comparison space with multiple instances like the one in Table 2, all would be designated non-links by the LSAP. Such behavior may lead to underestimation of overlap size estimation in practice; for example, in Table 2, the posterior probability of there being a match, 1âˆ’Pâ€‹(Zj=nğ’œ+j|Î³)1ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğ‘›ğ’œconditionalğ‘—ğ›¾1-P(Z_{j}=n_{\mathcal{A}}+j|\gamma), is quite high at 70%percent7070\%.

We consider several data scenarios characterized by different overlap sizes and error levels. To facilitate repeated sampling computations, we let nğ’œ=1000subscriptğ‘›ğ’œ1000n_{\mathcal{A}}=1000 and nâ„¬=50subscriptğ‘›â„¬50n_{\mathcal{B}}=50. We determine
the overlap size by setting the proportion Ï€ğœ‹\pi of records in â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B} that have links in ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} as Ï€âˆˆ{25%,50%,75%,100%}ğœ‹percent25percent50percent75percent100\pi\in\{25\%,50\%,75\%,100\%\}. In each scenario, we generate comparison vectors for F=3ğ¹3F=3 binary fields, where Î³i,j(f)=1superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘“1\gamma_{i,j}^{(f)}=1 when ğ’œi,f=â„¬j,fsubscriptğ’œğ‘–ğ‘“subscriptâ„¬ğ‘—ğ‘“\mathcal{A}_{i,f}=\mathcal{B}_{j,f} and Î³i,j(f)=2superscriptsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘“2\gamma_{i,j}^{(f)}=2 otherwise. For each field fğ‘“f, we set ğ¦f=(mf,1,mf,2)subscriptğ¦ğ‘“subscriptğ‘šğ‘“1subscriptğ‘šğ‘“2\mathbf{m}_{f}=(m_{f,1},m_{f,2})
and ğ®f=(uf,1,uf,2)subscriptğ®ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘“1subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘“2\mathbf{u}_{f}=(u_{f,1},u_{f,2})
to represent one of three error levels, where smaller values in mf,1subscriptğ‘šğ‘“1{m}_{f,1} accompanied by smaller values in uf,2subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘“2{u}_{f,2} indicate increased error levels in the linking fields. The parameter settings for each level are displayed in Table 3. These parameter choices are guided by the values of ğ¦fsubscriptğ¦ğ‘“\mathbf{m}_{f} and ğ®fsubscriptğ®ğ‘“\mathbf{u}_{f} from the RLdata500 data (Sariyar and
Borg, 2022) that we use in section 4.3.1. Briefly, the low error scenario represents minimal errors across all fields. The moderate and moderate-high error settings represent situations where errors are introduced into two of the three fields to varying extents. When referring to simulation results from the Fğ¹F-score point estimator and BRL estimator, we use F-Algo and BRL, respectively.

references: Table 4 displays the simulation results. For each metric, the averages are computed across N=1000ğ‘1000N=1000 independent simulation runs to ensure the Monte-Carlo errors remain below 10âˆ’6superscript10610^{-6}. At low error levels, the BRL estimator and the F-Algo estimator have comparable efficacy, both in the Fğ¹F-scores and overlap size estimates. In scenarios with moderate to moderate-high noise, the F-Algo estimator consistently outperforms the BRL estimator in the sense of higher Fğ¹F-scores and more accurate overlap size estimates. In these settings, the BRL estimator is overly conservative. In fact, it often declares all potential pairs as non-links, leading to Fğ¹F-scores of zero. Not surprisingly, the absolute performance of both estimators declines as overlap size decreases. With the lowest overlap and at least moderate errors, F-Algo tends to assign too many record pairs as links, whereas BRL tends to declare all record pairs as non-links.

Model A 0.71 0.71 32 32 50 (40, 122)

Model D 0.98 0.98 51 51 50 (49, 54)
references:
Table 5 displays the results for the RLdata500 illustration.
For Model A, Model C, and Model D, the Fğ¹F-score and estimated overlap size for F-Algo and BRL are identical. For model B, the F-Algo estimate has a marginally higher Fğ¹F-score than the BRL estimate. In all cases, the estimated overlap size is inside the 95% credible interval. These observations are line with results from the simulation study, where the two estimators offer similar results in the absence of substantial errors in the linking fields.
These results show that directly maximizing the expected Fğ¹F-score is compatible with anticipated behavior in these benchmark data.

Fğ¹F-score Est. Overlap True Overlap Overlap
BRL F-Algo BRL F-Algo 95% CI
Block 1 Model A 0.87 0.87 154 161 188 (150, 178)
Model B 0.74 0.75 117 138 188 (125, 161)
Block 2 Model A 0.51 0.66 58 88 144 (77, 110)
Model B 0.23 0.57 22 88 144 (59, 99)
references: Table 6 displays the results from the linkage with the Union Army data. In the case of Block 1, the BRL and F-Algo estimates perform similarly, with the same Fğ¹F-score for model A and only a marginal difference for model B. For the estimated overlap, the F-Algo estimate is closer to the truth. In the case of Block 2, when there is more ambiguity, the F-Algo estimates have substantially higher Fğ¹F-scores than the BRL estimates. Furthermore, the estimated overlaps from the F-Algo estimate are inside the 95% credible intervals, whereas the estimated overlaps for the BRL estimates are not. As seen previously, the F-Algo estimator tends to be less conservative than the BRL estimator in the presence of higher uncertainty, and thus can estimate the number of overlap links more accurately.
